questions.text: 1. A 52-year-old male presents with vomiting and complains of rotational vertigo upon turning his head on the bed in the morning. Which of the following is the best diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for a patient with vomiting and complaints of rotational vertigo upon turning his head on the bed in the morning is Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV).

Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is characterised by vertigo when the head is placed in a certain critical position. It is not associated with hearing loss or neurological symptoms. It is caused due to the disorder of the posterior semicircular canal.

The attacks are always provoked by changes in head position and caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals, usually dislodged from the posterior canal. A positive Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. It is due to otoconial debris getting into the posterior semicircular canal from the utricle. The patient complains of vertigo on moving or tilting the head to the affected side. 

Steps of the Dix-Hallpike manoeuvre:

* The manoeuvre starts with the patient in a sitting position.

* Their head is turned 45 degrees towards the ear to be tested.

* The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30 degrees below the horizontal.

* The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure.

* Now the examiner observes the patient's eye for nystagmus.



In most of the patients, it can be relieved by administering a therapeutic Epley manoeuvre on the affected side. Epley's manoeuvre is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals.

Epley's manoeuvre is given in the image below.



Other options:

Option A: Meniere's disease is characterised by vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus and a sense of pressure in the involved ear. Vertigo is of sudden onset, lasts for a few minutes to hours.

Option C: Vestibular neuritis is characterised by severe vertigo of sudden onset and lasts from a few days to weeks. There are no cochlear symptoms. 

Option D: Labyrinthitis causes symptoms of hearing loss along with unilateral vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo and associated nausea and vomiting.

questions.text:
2. A 4-year-old child presents with difficulty opening the mouth and tonic spasms in the limbs. The child gives a history of CSOM. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

CSOM- Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with difficulty opening the mouth (trismus) and tonic spasms in the limbs, with a history of CSOM, suggests the most likely cause to be Tetanus.

Tetanus is caused by Clostridium tetani, which is an anaerobic, gram-positive, spore-forming rod whose spores are highly resilient and can enter the body through abrasions, wounds, or the umbilical stump, in the case of neonates. It releases tetanus toxin (tetanospasmin), an exotoxin that enters the nervous system and causes disease.

The most common initial symptoms are trismus (lockjaw), muscle pain and stiffness, back pain, and difficulty swallowing. As the disease progresses, muscle spasm develops, and the laryngeal muscles are involved in early stages, leading to airway obstruction.

Generalised muscle spasms involve muscles of the entire body and are painful. Towards the second week of tetanus, autonomic disturbances are maximal as evidenced by gastrointestinal stasis, sweating, increased tracheal secretions and cardiovascular events like blood pressure fluctuations and heart block can occur. The diagnosis of tetanus is based on clinical findings. 

Other options:

Option A: Bezold abscess can occur due to mastoiditis following CSOM and leads to pain, fever, a tender swelling in the neck, and torticollis.

Option C: Meningitis is the most common intracranial complication of otitis media. There is fever with chills and rigours, headache, neck rigidity, photophobia, nausea and vomiting. It can also lead to cranial nerve palsies and hemiplegia. 

Option D: Sigmoid Sinus Thrombosis is characterised by Hectic Picket-Fence type of fever with rigours and headache.

3. Which of the following are the causes of stridor in neonates

1. Subglottic stenosis  2. Recurrent Respiratory papillomatosis 3. Haemorrhagic polyp 4. Laryngomalacia
questions.solution:
Subglottic stenosis and Laryngomalacia are the causes of stridor in neonates.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration, or both.

* Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.

* Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

* Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.



Other options:

Option 2: Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis presents with stridor in children and not in neonates.

Option 3: Haemorrhagic polyp may present with obstruction but not with stridor.

Pearl PM1799: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: 4. A middle-aged lady choked while eating fish and has associated symptoms of choking, hoarseness of voice and foreign body sensation in the throat. On examination, the fish bone was lodged in the pyriform fossa. What is the nerve responsible for irritation?

choices.text: Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of Superior laryngeal nerve

questions.solution:
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is responsible for irritation.

The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve runs submucosally in the lateral wall of the pyriform sinus. Foreign bodies may lodge in the piriform fossa and cause irritation. The nerve is easily accessible for local anaesthesia, and it is through this nerve that pain is referred to the ear in carcinoma of the piriform sinus.

Pyriform fossa lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the oesophagus and forms the lateral channel for food. It is bound medially by the aryepiglottic fold, the posterolateral surfaces of the arytenoid and cricoid cartilages. It is bound laterally by the thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text: 5. All are correct regarding juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, except
questions.solution:
Biopsy done under local anaesthesia is incorrect statement.

Biopsy of the tumour leads to profuse bleeding and is, therefore, avoided. If it is essential to differentiate it from other tumours, biopsy can be done under general anaesthesia with all arrangements to control bleeding and transfuse blood. 

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a benign but locally invasive tumour exclusively in adolescent males in the age group of 10-20 years. It arises from the posterior part of the nasal cavity that is close to the superior margin of the sphenopalatine foramen. These patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx that forms an angiofibroma when testosterone appears. Therefore, it is thought to be testosterone-dependent.

Angiofibroma can extend from its origin into the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, pterygomaxillary fossa, infratemporal fossa, cheek, orbits, and intracranial cavity, resulting in clinical features such as proptosis and frog-face deformity. The clinical features include:

* Profuse, recurrent, spontaneous epistaxis- most common

* Progressive nasal obstruction and denasal speech- due to a mass in the postnasal space

* Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion- due to obstruction of the Eustachian tube

* Sessile, lobulated, or smooth mass in the nasopharynx

* Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, cheek swelling, involvement of II, III, IV, and VI cranial nerves

Diagnosis is mostly based on clinical and imaging studies. Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the head is the investigation of choice that reveals anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus (Antral sign/Holman Miller sign), which is pathognomonic of angiofibroma as shown below.



Digital subtraction angiography shows the extent of the tumour with its vascularity. Surgery is the treatment of choice. Embolisation of the vessels can be done before surgery to reduce the risk of bleeding during the surgery. Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, and hormonal therapy can also be considered.

questions.text:
6. What are the indications of a cochlear implant?

1. Congenital hearing loss  2. Aminoglycosides induced profound hearing loss 3. Otosclerosis  4. Congenital malleus fixation
questions.solution:
Congenital hearing loss and aminoglycosides-induced profound hearing loss are types of sensorineural hearing loss and are indications of a cochlear implant.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device for severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and for those who do not benefit from a hearing aid. It works by directly stimulating the auditory nerve and bypassing the cochlear hair cells that are damaged. The principle of the surgery is to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea. An intact 8th nerve and the higher auditory pathway are prerequisites for surgery. 

Components of a Cochlear Implant are:

* External component: It consists of an external speech processor and a transmitter. 

* Internal component: It is surgically implanted and comprises the receiver/stimulator package with an electrode array.



The candidates for a cochlear implant should have the following features

* Severe or profound sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally

* No improvement with hearing aids 

* No medical contraindication for surgery

* Realistic expectation

* Good family and social support toward habilitation

* Adequate cognitive function to be able to use the device

Other statements:

Statement 3: Otosclerosis leads to conductive hearing loss, and hence cochlear implant cannot be used.

Statement 4: Congenital malleus fixation leads to conductive hearing loss, and hence cochlear implant cannot be used.

Pearl PM1817: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:



Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC). The electrodes of the cochlear implant are placed in the scala tympani and are passed through the round window from the middle ear.

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

* Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)

* Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway
